Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: AI-powered architecture for smarter ultrasound applications in healthcare
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to open new frontiers in medical imaging by introducing an innovative architecture for ultrasound systems. Ultrasonography is a widely used approach to perform clinical diagnosis and guide therapeutic procedures. However, technological bottlenecks in ultrasound engines currently prevent data intensive applications. By bringing the computational power directly within the ultrasound engine, this project will allow 3D functional ultrasound imaging in real-time with the highest quality. The innovation proposed will allow the generation of new ultrasound devices able to visualize body tissues in exceptional details and powered with data-driven computer-aided diagnostic applications. For the first time, ultrasound systems will have enough quality data to use algorithms of artificial intelligence (AI), which are expected to reduce time and costs associated with ultrasound analysis as well as improve patient outcomes. This project will also contribute to the advancement of research in the field of medical applications of ultrasonography technology by allowing the generation of new tools to be used in Research Institutes worldwide.

The proposed project will shift the paradigm in ultrasound engines. Today, ultrasound data-intense applications are restricted by the limitation in transmission speed of signals from the ultrasound engine to a computer where they have to be processed. This project proposes to integrate specialized computational power inside the ultrasound engine to allow real-time signal processing and image analysis where the signal is collected, hence reducing the requirements for the data transmission and processing. The activities proposed for this Phase I project will allow the company to build and validate a functioning prototype of high-performance scalable hardware architecture. The ability of the prototype to perform ultra-fast frame-forming imaging will be validated by simulating data-intensive operations. Concurrently, a minimal viable software will be developed to control, analyze and display in real-time the volume of data produced by the hardware, and to dynamically load applications and algorithms for clinical use. The feasibility study performed in this Phase I project will constitute the basis to expand the operation capabilities of the software platform and assess the ability of the prototype to perform real-time high speed imaging and recognition of bodily structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
White Eagle Sonic Technologies, Inc., d.b.a. Cephasonics Ultrasound developed "Itasca", an innovative new architecture for ultrasound imaging systems that supports ultra-fast frame-forming imaging (UFFFI). Cephasonics disruptive technology is based on: 1) a newly-designed hardware approach which brings the computational power of today's FPGA parallel processing  directly into the ultrasound engine, enabling ultra-fast processing of much greater data volumes in real time; 2) an enhanced open software platform that will be more supportive for developing and processing new AI-based applications, be able to dynamically process significantly larger fluxes of data and dynamically load and manage algorithms for data analysis.

In this Phase I SBIR project, Cephasonics was able to demonstrate a system with the ability to process 10,000 frames per second, resulting in a 10x advancement compared to the state of the art in commercially available ultrasound systems. A 64-channel ultrasound system was built, which could support up to 100Gbit/sec. In  future commercial versions, the platform design will support processing data at a speed >1Tbit/sec with a 64x channel multi-system.

Even though the system that was developed for the research project only utilized 64 channels, this new architectural design, in terms of both HW & SW, was designed to be extensible beyond 64 channels.  Thus, this design will enable the production of much larger systems from 128-4096 channels in the near future expanding the range of applications for the technology.

Additionally, while UFFFI has been feasible and used in select research areas, it has required much larger and expensive configurations, which have made it impractical for commercial medical applications.  This new architectural approach will dramatically lower the price point in the future for commercial ultrasound systems capable of delivering UFFFI and large data access and processing solutions.

The ability to access this increased computational power will make it possible to perform high-quality UFFFI in real time. Consequently, this new ultrasound architecture will enable researchers as well as medical product companies to design and develop new commercial ultrasound systems and solutions that can exploit UFFFI's huge potential to visualize body tissues in much greater detail as well as enable new AI data-driven computer-aided diagnostic systems.

These advancements will open new frontiers in functional medical imaging, fostering the widespread adoption of 3D functional medical imaging as well as the ability for ultrasound to provide clinicians greater real-time access to quantitative data and measurements related to medical procedures.  For example, the ability to perform real-time UFFFI will expand many fields of medical imaging, by making it possible to visualize and measure currently-invisible transient phenomena, including changes in blood volume in blood vessels for studies of cardiovascular stiffness or brain activity.
